jto.p5graphtheory

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • jto.p5graphtheory.Graph

  • public class Graph
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the Graph class. This is the main class for the graph theory library.

    A graph is an ordered pair of sets (V, E), where V is a set of Vertices and can be any set. E is a set of 2-element subsets of V, called Edges.

    This class allows for the modeling of Graph objects. This class also contains several static methods for performing operations on graphs and creating certain types of graphs.

    This library is meant to provide simple ways to visualize graphs and graph theory algorithms. Graph data structures can also be used to model many things.
    Version:
    2012.08.14
    Author:
    J. Taylor O'Connor

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addEdge(Edge e)
      This adds the given Edge to the Graph.
      This also adds the Edge's vertices if they are not in the Graph.
      void addEdge(Vertex a, Vertex b)
      This creates a new Edge connecting the two given vertices and adds it to the set of Edges.
      If either of the two vertices of the new Edge are not in this Graph, then they are also added.

      Adds a vertex to the TreeSet of Vertices or does nothing if the vertex is already in the graph.

      This clears the set of Edges.
      void clearVertices()
      This clears all the vertices in the graph.
      This also clears all of the edges, because the edges cannot exist in the absense of vertices.

      This tests to see if the Graph contains the given edge.

      Searches the Graph for the given Vertex.

      static Graph minimalSpanningTree(java.util.Collection<Vertex> vertices)
      This is an implementation of Kruskal's Algorithm for finding the minimal spanning tree for the given collection of Vertex objects.

      This will return a minimal spanning tree for the complete graph that contains these vertices.
      static Graph minimalSpanningTree(Graph g)
      This is an implementation of Kruskal's Algorithm for finding the minimal spanning tree of a graph.
      This will work for disconnected graphs, but it will return a Graph which contains multiple distinct trees.

      This uses the Triangulate library which can be found at:
      http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation
      static Graph triangulatedGraph(Graph graph)
      This will return a delaunay triangulation of the vertices in the source graph.
      This uses the Triangulate library which can be found at:
      http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation

      Note: This method does not take the edges of the source graph into consideration.

      • addVertex

        public void addVertex(Vertex v)
        Adds a vertex to the TreeSet of Vertices or does nothing if the vertex is already in the graph.
        Parameters:
        v - the Vertex

      • removeVertex

        public void removeVertex(Vertex v)
        Removes the Vertex from the Graph if it is present, or does nothing if it is not present. If the vertex is removed all of the edges incident to it are also removed.
        Parameters:
        v - the Vertex to be removed.

      • clearVertices

        public void clearVertices()
        This clears all the vertices in the graph.
        This also clears all of the edges, because the edges cannot exist in the absense of vertices.

      • containsVertex

        public boolean containsVertex(Vertex v)
        Searches the Graph for the given Vertex.
        Parameters:
        v - the Vertex in question.
        Returns:
        true if the Vertex is contained in this Graph.

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge(Vertex a,
           Vertex b)
        This creates a new Edge connecting the two given vertices and adds it to the set of Edges.
        If either of the two vertices of the new Edge are not in this Graph, then they are also added.
        Parameters:
        a - the first Vertex.
        b - the second Vertex.

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge(Edge e)
        This adds the given Edge to the Graph.
        This also adds the Edge's vertices if they are not in the Graph.
        Parameters:
        e - the new Edge to be added.

              Vertex b)
        This removes the Edge containing the two vertices from the set of edges if it exists in the Graph.
        Parameters:
        a - the first Vertex in the Edge.
        b - the second Vertex in the Edge.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a TreeSet of Edge objects that are the edges of the Graph.

      • randomCompleteGraph

        public static Graph randomCompleteGraph(int numberOfVertices,
                        processing.core.PApplet parent)
        This will generate a complete Graph with the specified number of vertices that are randomly distributed so that the coordinates of each vertex lie somewhere on the canvas of the parent PApplet.
        Parameters:
        numberOfVertices - The number of vertices.
        parent - the PApplet that is creating this Graph.
        Returns:
        A random complete Graph.

      • minimalSpanningTree

        public static Graph minimalSpanningTree(Graph g)
        This is an implementation of Kruskal's Algorithm for finding the minimal spanning tree of a graph.
        This will work for disconnected graphs, but it will return a Graph which contains multiple distinct trees.
        Parameters:
        g - The source Graph for the tree.
        Returns:
        The minimal spanning tree.

      • minimalSpanningTree

        public static Graph minimalSpanningTree(java.util.Collection<Vertex> vertices)
        This is an implementation of Kruskal's Algorithm for finding the minimal spanning tree for the given collection of Vertex objects.

        This will return a minimal spanning tree for the complete graph that contains these vertices.
        Parameters:
        vertices - A Collection of Vertex
        Returns:
        The minimal spanning tree.

      • spanningTree

        public static Graph spanningTree(Graph graph,
                 Vertex initialVertex)
        This is a breadth-first algorithm for finding a spanning tree of the given Graph starting from the specified Vertex. The resulting tree contains all the vertices in the original Graph.

        If this method is passed a complete graph, the spanning tree that results will just be a Graph with Edges connecting the initial Vertex to the rest of the Vertices in the source Graph.
        Parameters:
        graph - The source Graph.
        initialVertex - The initial Vertex.
        Returns:
        A spanning tree containing the vertices of the source Graph.

      • triangulatedGraph

        public static Graph triangulatedGraph(Graph graph)
        This will return a delaunay triangulation of the vertices in the source graph.
        This uses the Triangulate library which can be found at:
        http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation

        Note: This method does not take the edges of the source graph into consideration. You will get the same result regardless of which edges are present in the graph.
        Parameters:
        graph - The source Graph.
        Returns:
        A planar triangulated Graph.

      • triangulatedGraph

        public static Graph triangulatedGraph(java.util.Collection<Vertex> vertices)
        This will return a delaunay triangulation of the collection of vertices.
        This uses the Triangulate library which can be found at:
        http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation
        Parameters:
        vertices - A collection of Vertex objects to be triangulated.
        Returns:
        A graph that is a planar triangulation of the given collection of vertices.

      • toTriangles

        public static java.util.Collection<Triangle> toTriangles(Graph graph)
        This returns a list of triangles that make up the delaunay triangulation of the vertices in the source Graph. This is identical to the triangulate() method of the Triangulation library, which can be found here:
        http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation
        Parameters:
        graph - The source Graph.
        Returns:
        a Collection of Triangle objects that represent the trianglulation of the source Graph.

      • toTriangles

        public static java.util.Collection<Triangle> toTriangles(java.util.Collection<Vertex> vertices)
        This returns a list of triangles that make up the delaunay triangulation of the vertices in the source Graph. This is identical to the triangulate() method of the Triangulation library, which can be found here:
        http://wiki.processing.org/w/Triangulation
        Parameters:
        vertices - The collection of vertices to make up the triangulation.
        Returns:
        a Collection of Triangle objects that represent the trianglulation of the source Graph.
